column3: version of mini Claas set because I built it from spare parts back in November using the published images (and blueprint).

column1: Only rare parts are the red wheel rims and the 5L half beams that hold the attachment.

column2: t comment on the building process because of lack of instruction. Mine came together quite nicely. In the end you&#39
column3: ll have a good hand full of model (see picture).

column1: The odd angle of front cabin window and hood is achieved by a single connecting point to the roof. Therefore you may notice different (relative) angles in photos of the model.
There are three functions realised in this model:
- Rotation from rear axle to the tool (can&#39
column2: t decide whether this would be o mower or hay rake)

column1: Steering transmission is done by three horizontal 16tooth gears. The setup is only 3 studs wide but work fine for this model.

The attachment is driven from the rear axle making good use of the block that is known from the big linear actuator. The connection remains if the tool is lifted from the ground. Note that there is no supporting wheel. You have to adjust the height by hand and guessing.

I do not like the rear axle of the tractor: Both wheels are using the same (7L) axle. Therefore you will notice considerable resistance if the tractor is pushed in curves (obvious at least on flat surfaces). As the rear wheels are moving on circles of different diameter they would need to move at different speed. Bigger models have separate axles or even differential(s).
An improvement can be implemented with slight modification. I found it necessary (and feasible) to reinforce rear wheel suspension. Therefore 4L half beams are added as supports:
The 7L axle is replaced by two 3L studded axles that are pushed first through the wheel and then fixed inside the chassis:
For me this modification improved playability a lot.
(More pictures are available from my brickshelf folder.)

,TRUE,5,5,3,3,5 MartinT","2020-08-21T23:05:22.643Z","A cheap Technic set with god design and a lot of moving gears","

Function (gears)
What I liked about this set is all the different gears. Nine gears to be precise. To get so many in a small and cheap set is amazing. The steering uses three &ldquo
column3: just to extend the connection point. The rear attachment uses two &ldquo
column9: the harvest. This is driven by the rear wheels. That connection uses a &ldquo
column17: . This is a nice way to learn how gears work with other gears. It is also nice to see these gears move when you turn the tractor upside down and move the wheels.

column1: The tractor looks nice with the three different colors. The shape of the tractor is very good. The hood looks right, and the slope shape of the front of the cabin is a smart design. The grey bush between the wheels looks like a step for getting in the cabin.

The new box art is so much better than the old. Now we have a full-size picture of the set and the background, covering the whole front. The old had a black bar on the side and on the bottom. This is removed in the new one.

Model A is a tractor for cutting and therefor the attachment is in the rear. Model B is a harvester for gathering the harvest from the model A and therefor the attachment is in the front. Therefor the model A can look similar to the model B. It is basically the same thing expect the cabin is turn 180. Also, the model A has the steering in the front and model B has it in the back.

This Technic set is cheap but has amazing design and functions. The moving gears is a great way to learn about how gears work. This set is also a 2 in 1. They look the same, but model A is a tractor and model B is harvester. This set is my favorite cheap set, because of the gears and the design.
